oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Testimonies of Exemplary Caribbean Women Educational Leaders
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Conrad, Dennis A.
Conrad, Deborah J.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This study recognizes and honors the contributions and opinions of three exemplary educational and socialinstitutions at national levels in Trinidad and Tobago. They emerged as leaders, despite the dominantpatriarchy, pervasive bureaucracy, and elitist hegemony characteristic of "developing" countries. Thetestimonies of these women in leadership reveal glimpses of how they evolved as community leaders andtheir perceptions on what is critical to educational leadership. This study uses oral history methodology todevelop thick narratives and aims to share, celebrate, and value the lessons of these participant-exemplars.Findings from the study reveal leadership as an evolutionary process, nurtured by spirituality, community,and a sense of gender-equity--along with inter-relatedness--in the lives of the participants
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Education Leadership Research Center, Texas A&M University
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Advancing Women in Leadership Journal; Vol. 24 (2007 Spring)
